questions.text: A 34-year-old woman underwent near total thyroidectomy. She was started on levothyroxine. What hormone is produced in the peripheral tissues when levothyroxine is administered?
questions.solution:
• L-thyroxine (levothyroxine, a synthetic form of T4) is peripherally converted to T3 (biologically active) and rT3 (biologically inactive), Indicated in Myxedema & Hypothyroidism. Side effects are
    • Sweating, heat intolerance
    • Tachycardia, palpitations, arrhythmias, chest pain
    • Tremors
    • Weight loss (this drug is sometimes misused by patients trying to lose weight)

questions.text: A 54-year-old man with diabetes presents to clinic for a routine checkup. His blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. His last urinalysis showed a urine micro-albumin of 150 mcg. What is the most appropriate initial antihypertensive for this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient with diabetes has been diagnosed with hypertension and diabetic nephropathy. Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are the first-choice medications for patients with diabetes and hypertension. This is caused by the combined effect of ACE inhibitors as an antihypertensive and its renal protective effects.
  • Option(A): Doxazosin is an alpha1-selective-blocker that is used to treat hypertension as well as urinary retention secondary to benign prostatic hyperplasia.
  • Option(B): Hydrochlorothiazide is a thiazide diuretic that is the most common initial medication for essential hypertension. Because of the patient having diabetes with the initial stages of protein-losing nephropathy, lisinopril is a better choice as the initial antihypertensive.
  • Option(D) : Metoprolol is a beta1-selective blocker that may be used as an initial antihypertensive in patients with compensated CHF or history of coronary artery disease.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is admitted after consuming multiple tablets. The signs suggest that the drug is a cholinomimetic with little or no vascular effect, little or no CNS effect, and a duration of action of about 2-4 h. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these effects?
questions.solution:
Scenario Analysis: Child Ingests Cholinomimetic Drug

  • The presented signs include little or no vascular effect, little or no CNS (central nervous system) effect, and a duration of action of about 2-4 hours.
  • These signs suggest the child has ingested a cholinomimetic drug primarily acting on muscarinic receptors with limited or no nicotinic receptor activity.

Analysis of Options:

A) Bethanechol:

  • Muscarinic agonist.
  • Primarily affects the GI and urinary tract, leading to increased tone and motility.
  • Limited vascular and CNS effects.
  • Duration of action is relatively shorter.

B) Neostigmine:

  • Reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor.
  • Increases acetylcholine concentration at both muscarinic and nicotinic receptors.
  • Used for myasthenia gravis and reversing non-depolarizing neuromuscular blockers
  • Some CNS effects and vascular tone increase.

C) Physostigmine:

  • Acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, similar to neostigmine.
  • Pronounced muscarinic effects, limited nicotinic effects.
  • Used to reverse anticholinergic toxicity.
  • Has CNS effects, relatively short duration (30 minutes to 2 hours).

D) Pilocarpine:

  • Muscarinic agonist primarily affecting the eye and salivary glands.
  • Limited vascular and CNS effects.
  • Duration of action within 2-4 hours.
  • Used for glaucoma and xerostomia (dry mouth).

Conclusion:

  • Option D) Pilocarpine best matches the described effects, as it is a muscarinic agonist with the specified characteristics.
  • Options A, B, and C are less likely due to discrepancies with some of the described characteristics or additional effects not consistent with the scenario.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man takes 500 mg of levofloxacin immediately after completion of colonoscopy. The half- life of the medication is 20 h. At approximately how many half-lives will it take for 90% of the drug to be excreted from the body?
questions.solution:
At the first half-life, 50% of the drug will be eliminated from the body. (100/2)

At the second half-life, 75% of the drug will be eliminated from the body. (50/2)

At the third half-life, 87.5% of the drug will be eliminated from the body. (25/2)

Finally, at 3.3 half-lives, 90% of the drug will be eliminated from the body.

questions.text: A 67-year-old diabetic male is concerned with hypoglycemia as complication of OHA. Maximum risk of hypoglycemia among OHA ?
questions.solution: • The insulin secretagogues, especially those with a high potency (eg, glyburide and glipizide), can precipitate hypoglycemia, although the risk is less than that associated with the insulins.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought because of profound nausea, vomiting, headache, sweating, tachycardia, blurred vision, and dizziness. She says that she was having a glass of wine when she suddenly became ill. She was diagnosed with a duodenal ulcer, and treatment was started 3 days ago. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Helicobacter pylori (HP) is an acid-labile, spiral-shaped, gram-negative rod that is catalase-positive, oxidase-positive, and urease-positive. It resides in the mucosal layer and surface epithelial cells in the stomach. There is a strong association between HP and peptic ulcer disease (PUD). It is also associated with gastric adenocarcinoma and some lymphomas. Because this organism is difficult to eradicate with a single agent, a multiple medication regimen is often used.
  • Treatment regimens includes combinations of metronidazole, bismuth subsalicylate, omeprazole, and tetracycline or amoxicillin. This patient's signs and symptoms are highly suggestive of a disulfiram-like reaction caused by metronidazole. This reaction is caused by drugs that inhibit acetaldehyde dehydrogenase (similar to disulfiram) leading to an accumulation of acetaldehyde. Metronidazole, taken with alcohol, leads to elevated levels of acetaldehyde, which can cause headache, nausea and vomiting, facial flushing, tachycardia, sweating, blurred vision, dizziness, low blood pressure, and confusion.

questions.text:
A 49-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of muscle cramps and weakness. His home medications also include amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide. His blood pressure today is 160/90 mm Hg. The ECG are shown.

The addition of which of the following drugs is most likely to have prevented this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• This patient has manifestations of hypokalemia (e.g., muscle cramps, weakness, and U waves on ECG). Thiazide diuretics inhibit Na+ reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule, which increases K+ excretion and can lead to hypokalemia.
  • Eplerenone is an effective adjunct antihypertensive medication in patients with treatment-resistant hypertension. In addition, the drug's potassium-sparing properties are useful in patients who develop hypokalemia due to the use of potassium-wasting diuretics (e.g., loop and thiazide diuretics). Eplerenone inhibits the effect of aldosterone and, therefore, decreases K+ excretion in the distal convoluted tubule and collecting duct.

questions.text: Which of the following antimuscarinic agent is approved to use in COPD?
questions.solution:
• Ipratropium appears to be at least as effective in patients with COPD that includes a partially reversible component.
  • A longer acting, selective antimuscarinic agent, tiotropium, is approved as a treatment for COPD.

choices.text: Sentence 1 and 2 both are True and 2 is correct reason for 1
Sentence 1 and 2 both are True but 2 is not the correct reason for 1
Sentence 1 is True but Sentence 2 is False

questions.text:
Which of the following is TRUE for Propofol
1. Propofol produces most pronounced decrease in systemic blood pressure
2. Propofol decreases both preload and Afterload
questions.solution:
• Compared with other induction drugs, Propofol produces the most pronounced decrease in systemic blood pressure; this is a result of profound vasodilation in both arterial and venous circulations leading to reductions in preload and afterload. This effect on systemic blood pressure is more pronounced with increased age, in patients with reduced intravascular fluid volume, and with rapid injection.
    • Because the hypotensive effects are further augmented by the inhibition of the normal baroreflex response, the vasodilation only leads to a small increase in heart rate. Profound bradycardia and asystole after the administration of Propofol have been described in healthy adults despite prophylactic anticholinergic drugs.

questions.text:
Which is the right for receptor and its affinity for endogenous opioid peptide.
1. Mu has the maximum affinity for endorphins
2. Mu has minimum affinity for enkephalins
3. Kappa has maximum affinity for dynorphins
4. Delta has maximum affinity for dynorphins
A 48-year-old male took an overdose and manifest severe acute procainamide toxicity with markedly long QT, which of the following should be given immediately?
questions.solution: The most effective therapy for procainamide (and quinidine) toxicity appears to be concentrated sodium lactate due to increase sodium current by increasing the sodium ion gradient and reduce drug-receptor binding by alkalinizing the tissue. Pressor sympathomimetics is to be used to reverse drug-induced hypotension if indicated.

questions.text: A 23-year-old with otitis media treated with amoxicillin. The mechanism of action involves inhibition of
questions.solution: • Penicillins (and cephalosporins) bind to PBPs acting at the transpeptidation stage of cell wall synthesis (the final step) to inhibit peptidoglycan cross-linking. Synthesis of N-acetylmuramic acid is inhibited by fosfomycin. Vancomycin inhibits transglycosylase, preventing elongation of peptidoglycan chains.

questions.text: A 24-year-old girl presented with a painful, blistering rash. She has a history of bipolar disorder and has been on treatment for one month. Physical examination shows numerous coalescing bullae with epidermal detachment covering the face, trunk, and extremities. There are haemorrhagic erosions on the hard palate and buccal mucosa. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
• This girl's fever, blistering rash, positive Nikolsky sign, and recent medication change are consistent with a diagnosis of Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS). Toxic epidermal necrolysis is a severe form of this condition that involves > 30% of the skin.
  • Lamotrigine is an anti-epileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. It is one of the most commonly implicated triggers of SJS. Most cases of SJS develop within 2-8 weeks of initiating the offending medication.
  • The risk of developing SJS induced by lamotrigine therapy is greatest when high doses are used, so the initial dose should be low and increased slowly.

  1. Lithium is a mood stabilizer used to treat bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to lithium therapy have not been reported.
  2. Valproic acid is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is used to treat bipolar disorder. However, valproic acid is an extremely rare cause of SJS.
  3. Topiramate is an antiepileptic drug with mood-stabilizing properties that is sometimes used in conjunction with other agents to treat refractory bipolar disorder. However, cases of SJS attributed to topiramate therapy have not been reported.

questions.text: Examiner has asked you to identify the drug in viva-voice: "When administered by intravenous bolus, the blood pressure increases. When given orally for 1 week, the blood pressure decreases." Whar drugs you will pick up from the table ?
questions.solution:
The dual blood pressure effects of the drug suggest that initially it is causing a direct a-agonist vasoconstrictor effect, but when given for a week, it is accumulating in a blood pressure-controlling centre, eg, the CNS, and reducing sympathetic outflow via α2 effects. Here, out of given drugs, only clonidine acts as α2 agonist.

Option A: Prop

Option D: Prazosin is used in hypertension, acts as α1 blockers. NOT α2 agonist.

Option C: Tamsulosin, selective α1 blockers, acts on Internal urinary spinchter to contract, is used to reduce urinary hesitancy and prevent urinary retention in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy with a history of cystic fibrosis is brought to the physician for evaluation of recurrent episodes of productive cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath over the past month. Serum studies show elevated levels of IgE and eosinophilia. A HRCT of the lungs shown below. Antibiotic therapy is initiated. One week later, the patient continues to show deterioration in lung function. What will be your next step of management?
questions.solution:
• Failure to respond to antibiotic treatment in a patient with a history of cystic fibrosis, recurrent pulmonary exacerbations, elevated IgE levels, and CT findings of central bronchiectasis should raise concern for allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA).
  • Treatment is done with Oral glucocorticoids. For acute or recurrent ABPA (as seen in this patient), oral Itraconazole should be initiated

choices.text: He may feel dizziness, especially when in supine
He should take the drug in divided doses to avoid nausea
His symptoms will probably improve for a period of time but not indefinitely
He may feel uncontrollable muscle jerks.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man complains that he has had increased tremor and bradykinesia. He has started on levodopa, regarding side effects of the drug, the patient need not be informed that
questions.solution:
• In prescribing levodopa, the patient should be informed about adverse effects, including gastrointestinal distress, postural hypotension (dizziness while standing), and dyskinesias.
  • It is reasonable to advise the patient that therapeutic benefits cannot be expected to continue indefinitely.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents with intermittent pain and stiffness in her hands and feet. She takes ibuprofen for the pain, which provides good relief. She had her last attack 7 days ago. An X-ray of her hands is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?
questions.solution:
• This patient presents with a history of joint pain in > 2 small and medium size joints. The x-ray shows joint surface destruction and narrowed joint spaces of the metacarpophalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and wrist joints. In addition, the distal interphalangeal joints are spared, which is typical for rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Methotrexate is a disease-modifying antirheumatic drug (DMARD) and the first-line, long-term therapy for moderate-to-severe rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Early administration of DMARDs is crucial, because damage to the affected joints occurs early in the course of RA. Methotrexate is highly effective, well-tolerated, and inexpensive but has a slow onset of action (> 6 weeks).

For this reason, bridging therapy with glucocorticoids or NSAIDs is normally indicated during acute attacks, but this patient's last acute attack has already ended 7 days ago, obviating the need for bridging therapy.

choices.text: Can start using OCPs without any modification

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with type 1 diabetes mellitus comes to OPD for advice for starting of OCPs. Her current treatment regimen includes a long-acting subcutaneous insulin injection once a day. What would you advise?
questions.solution: As patient wants to start OCP, dose of the insulin should be increased

questions.text: The megaloblastic anemia that results from vitamin B12 deficiency is due to inadequate supplies of which of the following?
questions.solution: • Deficiency of vitamin B12 (cobalamin) leads to a deficiency in tetrahydrofolate and subsequently a deficiency of the dTMP required for DNA synthesis. Homocysteine and N5-methyltetrahydrofolate accumulate.

questions.text: Which of the following factors in Plasma concentration vs time graph is a measure of extent of absorption of a drug?
questions.solution:
Bioavailability

Bioavailability refers to the rate and extent of absorption of a drug from a dosage form administered by any route, as determined by its concentration-time curve in blood or by its excretion in urine.

It is a measure of the fraction (F ) of administered dose of a drug that reaches the systemic circulation in the unchanged form. Bioavailability of drug injected i.v. is 100%, but is frequently lower after oral ingestion because-

(a) the drug may be incompletely absorbed.

(b) the absorbed drug may undergo first pass metabolism in the intestinal wall/liver or be excreted in bile.

questions.text: Mechanism of action of Tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA)
questions.solution:
FIBRINOLYTIC DRUGS (Thrombolytics)

These are drugs used to lyse thrombi/clot to recanalize occluded blood vessels (mainly coronary artery).

The fibrinolytic system is activated to remove the fibrin. The enzyme responsible for digesting fibrin is a serine protease Plasmingenerated from plasminogenby tissue plasminogen activator (t-PA), which is produced primarily by vascular endothelium.

questions.text: Patient having recurrent attack of gout, which of the following drugs inhibits synthesis of uric acid?
questions.solution:
Uric acid synthesis inhibitors

Allopurinol

This hypoxanthine analogue was synthesized as a purine antimetabolite for cancer chemotherapy. However, it had no antineoplastic activity but was a substrate as well as inhibitor of xanthineoxidase, the enzyme responsible for uric acid synthesis.

Uses

Allopurinol is the first choice drug inchronic gout. It can be used in bothoverproducersandunder excretorsof uric acid. The more severe cases with tophi or nephropathy also respond well.

choices.text: Inhibition of RNA dependent RNA polymerase
Inhibition of DNA dependent RNA polymerase

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Remdesivir?
questions.solution: Remdesivir (GS-5734) is a phosphoramidite prodrug of a monophosphate nucleoside analog (GS-441524) and acts as a viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase(RdRp) inhibitor, targeting the viral genome replication process

questions.text: An elderly man presents with rigidity and tremors. On examination, he has blank facial expressions. Which of the following can be used to treat his condition?
Tocilizumab is an immunosuppressive drug used for Rheumatoid arthritis. It is a monoclonal antibody against
questions.solution:
Biological DMARDs

  1. TNF-α blocking agents

    TNF-α plays a major role in the joint destruction in patients with RA. Five drugsetanercept,adalimumab,infliximab,golimumabandcertolizumabact as DMARDs by blocking the action of TNF-α. All of these are given subcutaneouslyexcept infliximab which is given I.V. These drugs can causeactivation of latent tuberculosis.Infliximabisalso indicated in Crohn's disease psoriatic arthritis, Wegener's granulomatosis and sarcoidosis.

  2. Co-stimulation inhibitors

    Abataceptandbelataceptact by inhibiting CD80 and CD86 co-stimulatory molecules on antigen presenting cells. Interaction of these with CD 28 on T Cells is necessary for T-Cell activation. These are indicated for RA resistance to combination of methotrexate and TNF-α inhibitors.

  3. IL-6 receptor antagonists

    Tocilizumabis a monoclonal antibody against IL-6. It is approved for RA in combination with methotrexate. Tocilizumab is also approved now forcytokine release syndrome.Sarilumabis a new IL-6R antagonist for RA.

  4. Rituximab

    It is a monoclonal antibody that depletes B-cells and is used for RA incombination with methotrexate.

  5. Anakinra

    It is an IL-1 receptor antagonist used for RA.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an immune checkpoint inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Immune checkpoint inhibitors: James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjoreceived Nobel prizein physiology or medicine for their discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation. Normally, there are certain checkpoints, so that immune cells (like T-cells) do not attack self antigens. Certain receptors like PD-1 (programmed death receptors) or CTLA-4 (cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein) are present on T-cells. When ligands on other cells (PDL-1 or CD-80/86 respectively) bind to these receptors, T-cells are inhibited. Same method is utilized by some cancer cells to evade destruction from T-cells. These tumor cells over express the ligands like PDL-1 and inhibit T-cells. Monoclonal antibodies targeting these interactions result in disinhibition of these brakes and thus, T-cells can destroy cancer cells.

(a) PD-1 and PDL-1 inhibitors

  • Nivolumab,PembrolizumabandCemiplimabare monoclonal antibodies against PD-1 receptors on T-cells.
  • Atezolizumab,AvelumabandDurvalumabare monoclonal antibodies against PDL-1 present on cancer cells.

(b) CTLA-4 Inhibitor:

Normally CD-80 or CD-86 present on antigen presenting cells bind to CD- 28 present on T-cells. Cytotoxic T-lymphocyte Antigen-4 (CTLA-4) is a CD-28 homologue expressed on T-cells. Binding of this with CD-80/86 molecules inhibit the T-cells. Ipilimumab acts as CTLA-4 inhibitor resulting in T-cell activation and destruction of cancer cells. It is approved for treatment of malignant melanoma.

questions.text: A pregnant woman was prescribed indomethacin. What effect could be expected in the fetus?
questions.solution:
Ductus arteriosus closure During foetal circulation ductus arteriosus is kept patent bylocal elaboration of PGE2 by COX-2. Unknown mechanisms switch off this synthesis at birth and the ductus closes. When this fails to occur, small doses of indomethacin or aspirin bringabout closure in the majority of cases within a few hours by inhibiting PG production.

Administration of NSAIDs in late pregnancy has been found to promote premature closure of ductus in somecases. Risk of postpartum haemorrhage is increased. Prescribing of NSAIDs near term should be avoided

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is used for smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
Varenicline This α4β2 subtype NR selective partial agonist has been marketed as oral tablets in many countries to help smokingcessation.

Evidence has shown that the reward (reinforcing) action of nicotine is exerted through the α4β2 subtype of neuronal NRs which are mainly localized in nucleus accumbens and other mesolimbic areas.

Activation of these NRs by nicotine induces DA release whichproduces feelings of satisfaction/reward and has a reinforcing effect.

Since varenicline is a partial agonist at these receptors, it provides some level of nicotine substitution, but blocksthe reward effect of smoking.

Clinically it has been found to reduce craving as well asnicotine withdrawal symptoms in those who stop smoking.Utility of varenicline is limited by its side effects, which are mood changes, irrational behaviour, appetite and taste disturbances, sleep disorder and agitation. Warning has been issued that it may promote suicidal thoughts.

questions.text: Which of the following is the disadvantage of oxcarbazepine over carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Oxcarbazepine

This newer congener of carbamazepine is rapidly converted to an active

metabolite that is only glucuronide conjugated but not oxidized.

Risk of hepatotoxicity is estimated to be lower than with carbamazepine; but that of hyponatraemia is more. It may be better tolerated. Dose to dose it is 1½ times less potent.

questions.text: Which of the following is an adverse effect of long-term use of intermittent Teriparatide?
questions.solution:
There is a theoretical risk of osteosarcoma associated with teriparatide, particularly due to findings in animal studies. Although post-marketing surveillance has not shown a significant increase in osteosarcoma cases among humans, the FDA has previously issued warnings about this risk. The concern arises from studies in rats, where high doses of teriparatide were linked to an increased incidence of osteosarcoma. However, the risk in humans is considered minimal and nonsignificant based on current evidence. Nonetheless, caution is advised in patients with predisposing conditions.

  1. Subtrochanteric fracture

Incorrect: While teriparatide is used to treat osteoporosis and reduce fracture risk, it is not specifically associated with an increased risk of subtrochanteric fractures. In fact, teriparatide is intended to promote bone formation and reduce the risk of fractures, including hip fractures.

  1. Osteonecrosis of jaw

Incorrect: Osteonecrosis of the jaw is more commonly associated with bisphosphonates and certain cancer therapies rather than teriparatide. There have been no strong associations between teriparatide and osteonecrosis of the jaw in the literature.

  1. Net bone loss

Incorrect: Teriparatide is an anabolic agent that promotes bone formation and is used to increase bone density. It is not associated with net bone loss; rather, it is intended to improve bone mass and reduce fracture risk.
